keywords: new york state child victims act

timeline.summary: An FBI email chain, dated January 29, 2020, and February 7, 2020, discusses a medical list provided by a Victim Services Manager within the FBI Region. The email thread involves the (NY) and (RO) (FBI) offices and includes a reference to a previous, unusual interaction involving Geoffrey Berman. The medical list contains psychological services and a discussion about connecting the recipients with a therapist.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York requests a verification of whether Prince Andrew was interviewed by the FBI regarding the Jeffrey Epstein investigation, specifically referencing an article from Fox Wilmington. The request includes a link to the article and asks for the 302 document if the interview occurred.
An FBI file (EFTA00038461) was uploaded to UNET from Dropbox, originating from the FBI’s dropbox®icibi.gov address. The file, “Phone_conversation_with,” was sent on January 31, 2020.

Jill Greenfield, a partner at Fieldfisher, is communicating with the FBI regarding the Epstein investigation. She is coordinating with the AUSA (likely a US Attorney) to arrange a phone call to discuss details and questions. Greenfield’s client, a victim of sexual assault, is seeking an interview in London and asserts her right to anonymity under UK statute. The FBI has contacted her to explore the possibility of an interview, and she has provided available time slots for a call. There is a discussion regarding confirming the parameters of interest in the client and a caution given about verifying bank details.

Jill Greenfield, a partner at Fieldfisher, is involved in an investigation regarding the Epstein case, specifically concerning a client potentially involved in sexual assault. She is coordinating with the FBI (N. NY) and the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force.  She proposes scheduling a call to discuss details and the client's request for an interview in London, emphasizing the client’s right to anonymity under UK Statute.  Fieldfisher provides contact information and a disclaimer regarding bank details and email communication.

Jill Greenfield, a partner at Fieldfisher, is facilitating communication regarding an investigation related to the Epstein case. She is corresponding with a detective from the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force and the USAWS team, primarily discussing a potential client interview in London. The client is entitled to anonymity under UK Statute due to being a victim of sexual assault. Fieldfisher confirms they do not intend to change bank details and advises caution regarding any communication suggesting altered bank information.

A document titled "a302_february_2020.docx" was created on February 2, 2020, detailing pages 14-29 of notes taken by the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force. The notes relate to case EFTA00038445.

On February 2, 2020, at 9:24:31 AM EST, a query related to record P3O92965500A01 (Ghislaine Maxwell, JFK Airport, Term 4) was accessed by the user TASPD. The query originated from Person Lookout Query and was initiated by the FBI.

This document is a Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) import form, specifically an "Other" type, relating to a death investigation. The form, dated February 4, 2020, includes a psychology report and interview notes for the case ID 8: 90A-NY-3151227, involving Jeffrey Epstein as a victim. The report is classified as UNCLASSIFIED and designates the case as UNSUB(S).

Prince Andrew denied claims from Geoffrey Berman, U.S. Attorney for Manhattan, that he refused to cooperate with the FBI in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. Andrew stated no requests had been made, while Berman’s office maintained they had made multiple attempts to contact Andrew’s representatives. Andrew expressed anger and bewilderment regarding the allegations, and a source close to him stated he was awaiting contact from the FBI. Law enforcement sources affirmed Berman’s claims. Duncan Levin, a former prosecutor, viewed the situation as evidence of the authorities’ determination to investigate the complex network surrounding Epstein.

On February 5, 2020, an email was sent from the U.S. Department of Justice’s Public Affairs office to [REDACTED] regarding a news article about an Epstein accuser appealing to Prince Andrew to speak with the FBI.

On February 7, 2020, an individual requested an update on the upload of materials from an FBI CART hard drive containing data from seized and searched devices related to the Epstein case. The hard drive was received on January 21, 2020, and left with the recipient. The materials were to be uploaded to Relativity for privilege review, mirroring a previous review of Epstein search warrant returns. A subsequent batch of materials was anticipated shortly after the first upload.

An email chain discusses the receipt of a hard drive from the FBI CART containing materials from the Epstein case. The drive was processed from seized devices and includes data for upload and privilege review to Relativity. A follow-up email requests the return of the hard drive after the materials are uploaded, anticipating another FBI transmission. The privilege review is to be conducted identically to a previous review related to Epstein search warrant returns.

An FBI agent (NY) is requesting information about two sets of electronic devices. One set is a batch of search warrant returns from January 13, and the other is a hard drive received last week. The agent needs a list of the devices contained in each set. The communication involves an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York and a Senior Forensic Examiner.

Emails discuss the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case, originating from an FBI CART hard drive. The data was expected to be ready by the end of the week, with updates provided regarding its status. Instructions were given for PAE to categorize the data into PP and NP folders based on privilege terms and to send STR reports. The recipient requested the hard drive back once the materials were uploaded for a subsequent privilege review mirroring a previous process.

This document is a redacted email exchange between a U.S. Attorney’s office (Fieldfisher) and a partner at a UK law firm, Jill Greenfield, regarding an investigation into Jeffrey Epstein’s activities. Here’s a breakdown of the key content: *   **Initial Contact & Inquiry:** The exchange begins with Jill Greenfield responding to an inquiry about a potential interview with a client involved in the Epstein investigation. *   **Client Background:** The U.S. Attorney outlines the client’s situation – not a target, but likely a “suspect” analogue – and their limited knowledge based on witness accounts. They emphasize the client was likely a victim. *   **Interview Protocols:** The U.S. Attorney details their planned interview approach, emphasizing voluntary participation, the client's ability to decline questions, and potential for breaks. They outline desired topics of discussion, including the client's interactions with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. *   **Anonymity and Sensitivity:** The U.S. Attorney repeatedly stresses the importance of protecting the client's anonymity and avoiding re-victimization, noting their policies extend to protecting the identities of other victims. *   **Logistical Details:** The exchange covers logistical considerations such as the likely composition of the interview team (prosecutors and FBI officers), note-taking procedures (FBI Form 302), and the possibility of travel arrangements. *   **Confirmation & Next Steps:** The email concludes with a confirmation of the interest in speaking with the client and an offer to address any further questions. The document is heavily redacted, obscuring specific details related to the client and the investigation.

Emails discuss the upload and privilege review of data from a hard drive received from the FBI CART related to the Epstein case. The hard drive contains processed devices seized and searched. A request is made to upload the materials to Relativity for privilege review. A follow-up email inquires about the status of the upload, and another confirms the materials will be subject to a similar privilege review as previous Epstein search warrant returns. A second hard drive with additional materials is expected shortly.

On February 13, 2020, Trevor Schakohl of The Daily Caller sent a request for comment to the FBI regarding a circulating claim about human bones found near Little St. James, a former Jeffrey Epstein-owned island in the U.S. Virgin Islands. The request specifically inquired about the FBI’s findings since Epstein’s arrest on July 6. The FBI forwarded the request to the OPA and NPO.

Email correspondence regarding the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case, originating from an FBI CART hard drive. The data was initially expected to be completed within a day but was delayed. Updates indicated the data was “almost done” by February 12th, then expected to be ready by Monday morning. A check-in was made on February 4th regarding the status. The hard drive was received on January 21st and intended to be uploaded to Relativity for privilege review, with a request for its return after completion.

*   One individual (\[REDACTED]) identified a hotel option at the Beverly Hilton due to construction issues at the DoubleTree Santa Monica and its inclusion within the per diem budget. *   Another individual (\[REDACTED]) made a reservation at E2 (an unspecified hotel) as a backup due to availability concerns. *   A request was made for approval for travel between February 25th and 29th, including three days of interviews on February 26th, 27th, and 28th, and a request for a conference room on one of those days. *   The emails involve multiple redacted individuals and organizations, including the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force.

An individual ([REDACTED]) contacted multiple recipients, including FBI personnel, regarding a hard drive containing Epstein search warrant documents. The hard drive contained both new and potentially previously received materials, with numerous folders labeled with dates (e.g., "loadFiles" with a modified date of 11/14/19 and "NYC024362" with a modified date of 1/27/20). The sender was unable to determine which folders corresponded to specific devices or which materials were entirely new. The sender requested a spreadsheet detailing all devices, their extraction status, and the materials associated with each transfer to improve organization and review efficiency.

Multiple individuals are discussing the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case, specifically data received from the FBI CART. The data includes a hard drive processed from seized devices. Upload progress is being tracked, with updates stating the data is “large” and taking time to process. There are requests for status updates and confirmation of completion. A timeline of Monday morning is referenced for data readiness, and a follow-up is scheduled regarding the return of the hard drive once the data is uploaded.

The following emails discuss the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein investigation: *   Multiple individuals are requesting updates on the status of data received from the FBI CART, including a hard drive containing seized device materials. *   The data is initially located in the "Subpoena Returns" folder, then the “Search Warrant Returns” folder, and later in the “NP” and “STR” folders. *   The data is being segregated into “PP” hits and new data is loaded. *   The FBI is processing multiple hard drives related to the case. *   The privilege review process is being conducted, mirroring previous reviews of Epstein search warrant returns. *   The FBI anticipates further data transmissions.

Gloria Allred placed an advertisement on a school bus circling Buckingham Palace, featuring a picture of Prince Andrew and the message "If you see this man please ask him to call the FBI to answer their questions" regarding the Jeffrey Epstein case. She was discussing the stunt outside criminal court during the Harvey Weinstein trial, representing some of Epstein’s victims.  A photograph of the bus and a Press Association image accompany the communication.

Gloria Allred, an attorney representing some of Jeffrey Epstein’s victims, placed an advertisement on a school bus circling Buckingham Palace. The advertisement featured a picture of Prince Andrew and the message “If you see this man please ask him to call the FBI to answer their questions.” Allred discussed the stunt outside criminal court while attending the Harvey Weinstein trial.

This redacted document details an ongoing investigation into Jeffrey Epstein’s activities, specifically involving a U.S. Attorney’s office and a UK-based legal team (Fieldfisher). The primary focus is on speaking with a key witness, referred to as “her,” who has connections to Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. Here’s a breakdown of the key points: *   **Investigation Focus:** The U.S. Attorney’s office is investigating Epstein’s conduct, primarily seeking information about the witness’s interactions with him and Maxwell, including employment details and any instructions given. *   **Witness Comfort & Voluntary Participation:** The team emphasizes that any discussion would be entirely voluntary, with the witness having complete control over the topics discussed and the ability to decline questions at any time. *   **Meeting Logistics:** The team intends to meet in pairs (prosecutors and law enforcement) to ensure efficiency and demonstrate a supportive approach. They’re open to meeting in the U.K. or the U.S., depending on the witness’s preference. *   **Notes & Access:** Access to notes taken during interviews would be limited to the investigative team. The team is willing to check on specific access requests regarding anonymity. *   **Anonymity & Confidentiality:** The team maintains strict confidentiality regarding the identities of those they meet with, protecting the witness’s identity. They are careful to avoid triggering retraumatization during discussions about abuse. *   **Initial Scope:** The initial conversations would focus on broad aspects of the witness's relationship with Epstein and Maxwell, not necessarily delving into the specifics of abuse unless the witness is comfortable. The document is characterized by a cautious and sensitive approach, prioritizing the witness's comfort and well-being throughout the investigative process.

Several individuals are discussing the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case. The data, initially from FBI CART hard drives, is being processed and segmented into folders including "Subpoena Returns," "Search Warrant Returns," "NP," and "PP hits." There are requests for consolidation of subfolders and confirmation of data accessibility within Relativity. Updates regarding data loading progress and delays are provided throughout the exchange. One individual confirms receipt of a hard drive containing processed devices and requests its return upon upload.

The investigation is being conducted by U.S. prosecutors from the Southern District of New York. The client’s involvement is centered around her interactions with Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. Key points of communication include: *   **Initial Request for Information:** Greenfield’s client wants to help with the investigation and requests a meeting to discuss it. She wants a morning meeting with introductions and a discussion, followed by afternoon questions. She also requests permission for a US lawyer friend to be present. *   **Prosecutor’s Response:** The U.S. prosecutors outline their approach: voluntary discussions, no pressure to disclose uncomfortable topics, and a preference for introducing themselves and explaining the investigation. They typically work in pairs (two prosecutors and two officers) for efficiency. *   **Further Inquiry:** Greenfield asks about who would have access to notes and whether the client’s anonymity would be protected. The prosecutors confirm that investigative team members (prosecutors and FBI officers) would have access to notes, but disclosure is limited. They also ensure the client’s anonymity is maintained by not publicly disclosing the names of individuals they meet with. *   **Meeting Logistics:** The prosecutors suggest a meeting where they simply introduce themselves and explain the process, with no obligation for the client to discuss sensitive details. They emphasize that the meeting would be entirely voluntary and flexible. *   **Overall Approach:** The prosecutors stress a sensitive, careful approach to the investigation, prioritizing the client’s comfort and well-being, and confirming the client is not a target of the investigation.

Several individuals are discussing the upload and privilege review of materials related to the Epstein case, originating from FBI CART hard drives. Concerns are raised about the volume of data ("voluminous") and potential technical issues slowing the upload process. Suggestions are made to consolidate folders, create a saved search for easier access, and track the status of data releases. Updates are provided regarding the release of data from various sources (NP folder, STR data, FBI CART hard drive) and requests are made for assistance with uploading and managing the data within the Relativity platform.

*   The documents include both new and potentially previously received materials. *   There’s a significant lack of identification and tracking of the source devices and materials, leading to confusion about what is new and what has been previously processed. *   A centralized system (spreadsheet) is urgently needed to track devices, data transfers, and associated materials to manage the volume effectively. *   The team is struggling to determine the origin and completeness of the data due to absent labeling and documentation.

The document records email correspondence regarding the upload and privilege review of materials related to the Epstein case. The materials originated from a hard drive received from the FBI CART, containing data seized during searches. Discussions centered on locating the materials within the Relativity database, specifically under the “Search Warrant Returns” folder. There were concerns about the volume of data and potential issues with the vendor (PAE) releasing it. Updates were provided on the status of data uploads, including the release of the “NP” folder and segregated “PP hits.” Requests were made for guidance on folder structure and for the return of the hard drive once the materials were uploaded. The final email included a document named “STR_Epstein_Privilege Terms_02. I 4.2020.pdf”.

She initially requests a morning meeting with introductions and discussion about the investigation, followed by an afternoon question-and-answer session. The witness wants a friend, a US lawyer, to be present during the meeting. The investigating team (two prosecutors and two FBI officers) typically meets in pairs to ensure efficiency and prioritize the witness's comfort. They primarily focus on the witness's interactions with Epstein and Maxwell, including employment details and observations, without requiring discussion of specific abuse details unless the witness is comfortable. The team emphasizes that any meeting would be voluntary and the witness has the right to decline questions. They offer to travel to the UK to conduct the interview and are willing to pay for the witness's travel expenses. Access to notes will be limited to the investigative team and supervisors. Anonymity is maintained, and the team is committed to a sensitive approach to avoid re-victimization.

On February 23, 2020, Mark Anthony Taylor wrote to UK Treasury Select Committee Chairman Mel Stride, alleging a cover-up regarding Jes Staley's conduct at JP Morgan and the handling of emails related to Jeffrey Epstein. Taylor claims the FBI, FCA, and PRA were investigating Staley, but the TSC withheld key evidence, including blackmail emails from Epstein, that should have led to Staley's dismissal in 2015. He asserts Andrew Bailey (FCA) and Lisa Osofsky (SFO) refused to investigate, potentially due to collusion with the TSC. Taylor also alleges his friend was murdered for exposing the story and that Judge Worster, a High Court judge, was involved in suppressing the truth. He questions Bailey’s suitability for a role at the Bank of England and suggests investigations into Andrew Bailey and Mark Carney concerning the LC&F scandal. Taylor accuses Roger Jenkins of attending Epstein’s parties and demands an investigation.

*   The sender believes the UK Treasury Select Committee (TSC), led by Mel Stride, suppressed evidence regarding Staley's emails and Epstein’s activities, hindering investigations by the FBI, FCA, and PRA. *   The sender accuses Andrew Bailey (FCA) and Lisa Osofsky (SFO) of refusing to investigate Staley, suggesting a cover-up orchestrated by the TSC. *   The sender highlights the death of a friend who investigated the story, alleging intimidation and stonewalling by Judge Worster, who issued restraining orders against the sender. *   The sender questions the integrity of individuals involved, including Judge Worster, Lord Burnett, and Roger Jenkins, suggesting potential corruption and connections to Epstein’s activities. *   The communication includes a letter attached to the TSC and MP Theo Clarke, outlining these concerns.

prosecutors (specifically an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York) and a UK law firm (Fieldfisher) regarding an investigation into Jeffrey Epstein’s activities. The primary communication is between Jill Greenfield (a partner at Fieldfisher) and the Assistant U.S. Attorney. **Key Points:** *   **Initial Inquiry:** The U.S. prosecutors are seeking to speak with a specific individual ("her") who had connections to Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. *   **Client’s Concerns:** The individual (“her”) expresses a desire to meet, outlining requests for a morning meeting, questions about the investigation, and the presence of a friend (a U.S. lawyer) who could be present for support. *   **Prosecutor’s Response:** The prosecutor outlines their approach: a voluntary, flexible discussion where the client controls the topics discussed; meetings in pairs; and a willingness to travel to the U.S. to conduct the interview, offering to cover travel and lodging costs. *   **Logistics & Protocol:** The prosecutor explains their typical interview process – two prosecutors and two officers in the room; note-taking by an agent and subsequent FBI Form 302 reports; and limited dissemination of notes. They also address anonymity concerns, stating they do not disclose the names of witnesses. *   **Sensitivity & Trauma:** The prosecutor emphasizes a sensitive and careful approach, avoiding re-victimization, and offering to simply introduce the team and explain the process without requiring the client to discuss abuse. *   **Further Communication:** The parties agree to continue communication via email or phone and explore the possibility of the prosecutor traveling to the UK to meet.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York contacted “a” (NY) (FBI) on February 25, 2020, regarding an individual named Jack Scarola. The attorney provided the FBI with contact information for Scarola’s attorney, anticipating a potential future contact from Scarola.

On February 26, 2020, an FBI agent (“-N.”) requested assistance with the Maxwell investigation, specifically related to the “GM case.” The request included reviewing message pads seized from Jeffrey Epstein’s residence for messages related to individuals involved in the case. It also involved examining Maxwell’s current finances, including assets, transfers from Epstein’s account, and financial information regarding UK and French citizenship. Finally, the agent requested the current tracking document for a hotline and interview notes from a previous interview.

On February 27, 2020, an email thread discusses individuals treated by therapists in West Palm Beach related to Jeffrey Epstein victims. One sender requests confirmation of names and session details, inquiring about extended sessions and FBI reimbursement. Another sender, Brittany Edwards, provides contact information (address, phone numbers, website) and offers assistance. A separate email from February 27, 2020, lists names of victims treated in West Palm Beach and mentions exceeding 6 sessions covered by the FBI, with questions about additional FBI coverage and reimbursement.

On February 27, 2020, the Bureau of Prisons placed the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York on modified operations after receiving information about a possible contraband introduction. Subsequent investigation led to the recovery of cell phones, narcotics, and homemade weapons. On March 5, 2020, a loaded firearm was discovered, maintaining the facility’s modified operations status. The Bureau of Prisons provided updates to the Office of Inspector General and the Federal Bureau of Investigation and affirmed its commitment to safety and accountability.

An NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force investigation, code-named "GM," is underway concerning Maxwell. A TECS system notification indicates Maxwell’s name has been run three times in the past month. An update on an Accurint check revealed no properties owned by Maxwell.  An Assistant United States Attorney requests assistance with reviewing message pads seized from Epstein’s residence, analyzing Maxwell’s finances (including potential transfers and FinCEN alerts), identifying Maxwell’s current properties, obtaining the current hotline tracking document, and confirming Maxwell’s UK and French citizenship along with interview notes.

The email chain discusses a “Keep Open Letter” for USAA bank. It involves requesting information about Ghislaine Maxwell, Scott Borgerson, and their USAA account number. Mandy, an FBI Special Agent, is coordinating with Alex and James C. Castafio (Manager of AML Investigations and Compliance) to send the letter.  EFTA00038404 and EFTA00038405 are identified as case numbers.

On March 2, 2020, a Special Agent from the FBI New York (Child Exploitation & Human Trafficking) sent a Keep Account Open Letter to [REDACTED] as requested.  A copy of the KAO template was also sent by AML FIU, Enterprise Risk and Compliance from USAA, Tampa Crosstown, requesting the SAR (Suspicious Activity Report) be filed. Once filed, the SAR request for backup documentation should be submitted to the Information Sharing team using USAA case number 02002421770 and DCN [TBD].

A U.S. Attorney’s Office (Southern District of New York) is requesting information from the FBI regarding discovery requests from Noel’s counsel, specifically items 1-13, detailed in a letter attached. The request does not require any new investigation.

An email exchange occurred on March 2, 2020, regarding a victim of Jeffrey Epstein. One individual ([REDACTED]) inquired about the victim’s contact information and requested assistance with therapy referrals and potential eligibility for NY State Crime Compensation. Another individual, CFmills@fbi.gov, responded with the victim’s contact information and information about the NY State Crime Compensation program. A third individual ([REDACTED]) sent a follow-up email referencing the FBI Victim Specialist and the victim’s meeting with M. and yi.

An email chain discusses a request for a “Keep Open Letter” for USAA bank. The request involves providing names and Social Security Numbers (SSNs) for individuals, including Ghislaine Borgerson and Scott Boerson, and referencing communication with a USAA Investigations and Compliance representative named Tam Crosstown. An attached template from USAA is referenced, along with a case number EFTA00025123 and a follow-up to be sent to the FBI New York VCAC/Human Trafficking Special Agent.

*   **Communication Chain:** Emails detail a request for assistance from the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Task Force to a US Attorney’s office (Southern District of New York) regarding the investigation. *   **Information Requests:** The US Attorney requests assistance with several tasks, including: reviewing message pads from Epstein’s residence, investigating Maxwell’s financial records and assets (including properties and potential transfers), tracking leads via a hotline, and confirming Maxwell’s citizenship details. *   **TEC System Notifications:**  There have been multiple TECS system alerts related to Maxwell’s name, indicating potential monitoring activity. *   **Ongoing Efforts:** The US Attorney confirms they've already performed an Accurint check on Maxwell and found no owned properties.

This document is a series of emails discussing the handling of search warrant documents related to Jeffrey Epstein’s case. Key points include: *   Requests for an accounting of the data, specifically a spreadsheet detailing devices, review status, and transfer information. *   Challenges with identifying and tracking the vast amount of data (over a million documents across multiple devices and media). *   Issues with duplicated or outdated materials on a hard drive received, requiring clarification on what is new. *   Discussions about scheduling a meeting to coordinate efforts and ensure everyone is on the same page regarding the data’s status and organization. *   Concerns about the need for a clear system to track device extraction, dumping, review, and transfer processes.

Multiple parties (including FBI personnel and a vendor named PAE) are involved in the upload and privilege review of data related to the Epstein case. There are concerns about the volume of data, specifically repeated documents and large file sizes. The data is being transferred from various sources, including FBI CART hard drives, and there are requests for it to be organized and moved to the appropriate Relativity folders (Search Warrant Returns). There are delays and questions regarding the upload process and the need for duplication. Discussions revolve around folder structure, data accessibility, and the timeline for completion of the privilege review.

On March 4, 2020, Brittany Henderson, a Victim Specialist at the FBI New York Office, sent an email to [REDACTED] containing an application related to an Epstein victim. The email was forwarded from an unknown sender and attached files named “Untitled.pdf” and “ATT00001.txt”. The subject line was “Epstein Victim”.

An individual received a dataset from the FBI related to the US v. Epstein case. The dataset contained issues including a lack of functionality to link emails and attachments, a missing link between the load file and native files, and mismatched control numbers. The sender requested the FBI to resend the data with these corrections applied.

An email chain discusses issues with a dataset provided by the FBI related to the US v. Epstein case. The dataset lacks functionality to link emails and attachments, has a broken link to native files, and contains mismatched control numbers. The sender requests the FBI to correct these issues and resend the data.

On March 6, 2020, at 6:00:27 AM EST, ICE (through Person Lookout Query) viewed a record for Jeffrey Epstein (P3N06596100A01) originating from ICE-VIENNA AU, HSI ATTACHE. The query was initiated by ICE and flagged as a “SUBJ QUERY HIT.” The email was sent from donotreply@cbp.dhs.gov.

*   The travel request requires approval from the ADIC and AD of IOD. *   CACHTU will provide funding for the travel. *   The purpose of the trip is an interview/proffer with a witness/co-conspirator residing in London. *   The expected travel dates are March 17th-20th, 2020. *   Estimated expenses include airfare, hotel, parking, taxi, and M&IE (meals and incidentals), totaling $4,250. *   The request is being made due to temporary travel restrictions related to the coronavirus and the potential importance of the interview to a forthcoming indictment.

On March 8, 2020, an individual reported a tip to the FBI regarding alleged child sex trafficking and infanticide involving Jeffrey Epstein and their uncle, dating back to 1984. The complainant, using an alias, detailed a series of events involving multiple individuals and yachts originating from Mona Lake, MI.  The complainant claims to have been forced into sexual activity at age 13 while pregnant and alleges involvement of Donald Trump and the murder/disposal of their newborn daughter in Lake Michigan. The initial contact was with an NYPD detective (name redacted) who investigated the claims. The tip originated from an IP address in Albuquerque, NM, and includes information regarding the complainant’s address, contact details, and witness information.  Several pieces of information are redacted.

Prince Andrew has hired a leading extradition lawyer to defend against an FBI investigation into his connections with Jeffrey Epstein. The article originates from The Sun and was published on March 8, 2020.

An FBI Special Agent from the New York Field Office’s Violent Crimes Task Force sent a 302 form regarding seized hard drives associated with DVR 2 to an individual at [REDACTED] on March 9, 2020. The email included a PDF attachment detailing the seizure and referenced prior email correspondence concerning the DVRs and video system.

On March 9, 2020, an FBI Special Agent from the New York Field Office reported that priority cameras from dvrl had completed downloading. A contractor was installing a replacement system, with the expectation of new cameras recording by that night. The A7 Agent and a BOP employee would remain to oversee the tech’s work, and the agent planned to secure the room with evidence tape upon completion. Video was to be staged on opwan and ttk for review and transcoding, and the DVR was scheduled for shutdown and collection the following day.

On March 9, 2020, the FBI New York Field Office’s Violent Crimes Task Force received an update from the Digital Forensic Analysis Unit (DFAU) regarding DVR 1. DFAU obtained the password from the MCC Contractor and is currently reviewing the data. DVR 2, covering the MCC SHU, is not running and the MCC Contractor is scheduled to begin working with DFAU in the OTD Lab the following day.

FBI agents are attempting to extract video surveillance from the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) to investigate a suicide. Due to hard drive failures in DVR system #2 and a delay in NiceVision’s system installation, the plan involves immediate removal of DVR system #2 for hard drive reconstruction by DFAS-DSAU. Simultaneously, FBI FAVU is extracting video from DVR system #1, while C-19 maintains a security presence. The goal is to reconstitute both systems and review all recorded footage for evidence, with a significant risk of corrupted or encrypted hard drives from system #2. This process is estimated to take several weeks.

The documents detail significant challenges in reviewing a massive collection of digital evidence seized in connection with Jeffrey Epstein’s case. The FBI’s data delivery format is problematic, lacking proper linking between emails, attachments, and native files. The data set includes over a million documents with no clear connection between files, leading to an inability to effectively review or produce the materials for defense counsel. Key issues include: *   **Data Format Problems:** Emails lack attachments, load files don't link to native files, and control numbers don’t match, making review nearly impossible. *   **Volume and Lack of Tracking:** The sheer volume (over a million documents) combined with a lack of clear device identification and review status makes tracking nearly impossible. *   **Redundant Data:** Multiple copies of drives and repeated data transfers complicate the situation. *   **Request for Organization:** The sender repeatedly requests a spreadsheet detailing device information, review status, and transfer details to facilitate efficient review and production of materials.

*   **Prince Andrew and Epstein:** The SDNY was investigating potential co-conspirators of Jeffrey Epstein, and Prince Andrew had shut down voluntary cooperation with the investigation, leading to a possible criminal inquiry. *   **MCC Issues:** There were concerns about the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in Lower Manhattan due to structural problems, staffing issues (including the transfer of Captain Jermaine Darden), and a smuggling incident involving a gun. Several MCC personnel were facing scrutiny. *   **Horse Racing Doping Scandal:** The FBI was investigating a widespread doping scheme involving trainers, veterinarians, and suppliers in horse racing, leading to the indictment of 27 individuals. Jorge Navarro was central to this scheme, and his horse, X Y Jet, died due to excessive drug use. *   **Joshua Schulte Investigation:** The FBI was investigating computer engineer Joshua Schulte, who had leaked classified C.I.A. documents to WikiLeaks. Schulte was eventually convicted of contempt of court and making false statements. *   **Lawrence Ray Case:** Lawrence Ray, who had forced a former college student into prostitution, was arrested and charged with sex trafficking. *   **Judge Walton's Criticism:** Judge Reggie Walton criticized Attorney General William Barr for allegedly misleading the public about the Mueller Report, raising questions about Barr's independence. *   **Coronavirus Restrictions:** The SDNY implemented new restrictions barring entry to courthouses for anyone who had recently traveled to or come into contact with individuals affected by the coronavirus outbreak.

An FBI Special Agent from New York is requesting approval for foreign travel to London for two agents and SDNY AUSA’s from March 16th-20th to conduct an interview related to the Jeffrey Epstein investigation. The purpose is to interview a crucial witness, the former personal assistant to Epstein, who is a key eyewitness to a sexual abuse incident and potentially holds information vital to indicting a co-conspirator. The witness and their attorney reside in London and are unwilling to travel to the US. CACHTU will provide funding for the request, which bypasses standard IOD approval due to travel restrictions.

The document contains email exchanges regarding the upload and privilege review of extensive search materials related to the Epstein case. The document details a significant challenge in reviewing a massive collection of electronic data seized in connection with the Epstein investigation. The FBI’s forensic team in New York received over 1.4 million documents from multiple sources, including hard drives and CDs, but the data is severely disorganized and lacks crucial metadata. Specifically, the files are not linked to their originating devices, there’s no indication of whether they represent full or partial data sets, and control numbers are inconsistent. The team repeatedly requested a standardized system—a spreadsheet identifying devices, review status, and data transfers—to facilitate the review process, but faced delays due to network issues and a lack of coordination. Multiple emails exchanged between FBI personnel and U.S. Attorneys highlight the difficulties in tracking the data, the need for a clear accounting of received materials, and the urgency of establishing a systematic review approach before significant time is lost.

Virgin Islands. *   The investigation includes examining Epstein’s jail calls and custodial materials, potentially issued through grand jury subpoenas. *   Communication occurs between Nate (Assistant U.S. Attorney, District of the Virgin Islands) and Geoffrey Berman (USANYS) to coordinate efforts and identify a contact person within Sony. *   The FBI and IRS-CI are also participating in the investigation. *   The initial inquiry was prompted by a USVI-based FBI and IRS-CI team opening an investigation into the estate and bank.

This document consists of a series of emails detailing a complex investigation into potential fraud and illicit activities involving prominent figures and financial institutions. The core allegations center around a network involving Leon Black (Milken Degenerate Fat Leon Black), Steve Schwarzman, Apollo, Kushner Companies, and others. Key points include: *   **Insurance Industry Takeover:** Concerns about Milken-linked individuals (Black, Schwarzman) orchestrating the takeover of the insurance industry through acquisitions like Athene, Harrahs, and Caesars. *   **Fraudulent Investments:** Allegations of fraudulent investments in junk bonds, real estate, and shell companies like ESWW (Environmental Solutions Worldwide) and Financial Trust Company Inc. (Epstein’s Trust). *   **Money Laundering:** Suspicions of money laundering schemes facilitated through various entities, including Greek shipping companies and the manipulation of stock prices. *   **SEC Involvement:** Criticism of the SEC’s handling of investigations, suggesting it was either complicit or ineffective in preventing these activities. The emails also question the motivations of individuals like Stephanie Avakian and the effectiveness of the SEC’s oversight. *   **Connections to Epstein & Kushner:**  A strong focus on connections between Epstein, Black, Schwarzman, and the Kushner family, raising concerns about potential illegal activities and influence within the White House. *   **Trump Administration Connections:**  References to individuals like Chad Readier, Andrew Ekonomou, and former FBI Director Robert Mueller III’s involvement in advising the Trump administration. *   **Ongoing Investigation:** The emails portray the author as actively pursuing these allegations and seeking to expose what they perceive as systemic corruption within the financial system. The emails are characterized by strong language, accusations of criminality, and a sense of urgency and frustration. They point to a pattern of potentially connected illegal activities involving significant financial figures and institutions.

Seidel, Section Chief of the Record/Information Dissemination Section of the FBI, in support of a motion for summary judgment in a civil case (Radar Online LLC v. Federal Bureau of Investigation). *   **Seidel’s Role:** Seidel’s declaration details his oversight of the FBI’s handling of FOIA and Privacy Act requests, specifically concerning the investigation and prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein. He has extensive experience within the FBI related to these types of requests. *   **Case Background:** The case involves a FOIA request submitted by James Robertson regarding the FBI’s investigation and prosecution of financier Jeffrey Epstein. The FBI initially processed 11,571 pages of responsive records, withholding them based on FOIA Exemptions 3, 5, 6, 7(A), 7(C), 7(D), and 7(E). *   **Record Processing:** The FBI utilized a central records system (CRS) to locate and process the records. They used automated case support systems and conducted a categorical review, applying exemptions to specific document categories. *   **Exemption Justifications:** The FBI withheld information based on concerns related to pending law enforcement proceedings (Exemption 7(A)), privacy interests (Exemptions 6 & 7(C)), protection of confidential sources (Exemption 7(D)), and the protection of law enforcement techniques (Exemption 7(E)). *   **Sealed Documents:** 38 pages of the records are sealed due to a court order. *   **Segregation Efforts:** The FBI made efforts to segregate non-exempt information from exempt material where possible.

This agreement stems from a civil enforcement action alleging the estate misused funds to facilitate Epstein’s sex trafficking operation. Key elements of the revised fund include: *   **Victim Advocacy:** Involvement of a victim advocate and an expert on child sexual abuse. *   **Funding Flexibility:** Dedicated funding for those who haven’t come forward or are dissatisfied with the claims process. *   **Privacy Protections:** Safeguards to prevent the sharing of victim information with the estate. *   **Counseling Services:** Access to counseling and referral services through the FBI Victim Services program and Child USA. *   **Oversight:** Approval of the budget by the Probate Court and monthly reporting to the AG’s office. This document details the resolution of disputes surrounding a victim compensation fund for Jeffrey Epstein’s estate, involving the Virgin Islands government and Epstein’s attorneys. Key points include: *   **Agreement in Principle:** The Attorney General (AG) of the Virgin Islands reached an “agreement in principle” with the estate’s attorneys for a victim compensation program after a prolonged legal battle. *   **Revised Protocol:** The fund now includes significant reforms, notably the involvement of a victim advocate and expert on child sexual abuse, dedicated funding for dissatisfied claimants, protections for victim information, and access to counseling and referral services through the FBI Victim Services program and Child USA. *   **Initial Legal Disputes:** The AG initially filed a civil enforcement action against the estate and companies, citing misuse of tax benefits and restrictions on settlement payments due to liens on the estate’s assets. *   **Core Changes:** The agreement removes the estate’s initial demand for broad releases from victims, ensuring a fairer and legally sufficient process. The estate has agreed not to disclose information obtained through the program and to allow the Probate Court to review the program’s budget. *   **Ongoing Investigation:** The US Attorney for the Virgin Islands continues to pursue legal action against Epstein’s criminal enterprise.

Initially, liens on the estate’s $600 million were preventing payouts to victims due to legal disputes and allegations of misuse of funds by Epstein and his attorneys. The Attorney General (AG) Denise George, in conjunction with Epstein’s legal team and victim advocates (including Marci Hamilton of Child USA), reached an “agreement in principle” to revise the compensation fund protocol. Key aspects of the revised fund include: *   **Victim-Oriented Process:** The fund is designed to be more fair and credible, prioritizing the needs of survivors. *   **FBI Victim Services & Child USA:** Access to counseling and referral services through these programs is included. *   **Protections for Victims:** Measures were put in place to safeguard victim information and prevent its use against them. *   **Independent Oversight:** The program’s administrative budget requires approval by the Probate Court, and monthly reporting is mandated. The agreement effectively removes the obstacles preventing payouts, allowing victims to receive compensation without the need for lengthy and potentially traumatic legal proceedings. The U.S. Attorney’s Office continues to pursue legal action against the estate related to the CICO lawsuit.

The document details a resolution regarding a victim compensation fund for Jeffrey Epstein’s estate in the Virgin Islands. Key points include: *   **Agreement Reached:** Attorneys for Epstein’s estate and the Virgin Islands government have reached an “agreement in principle” for a victim compensation program. *   **Initial Dispute:** The original fund proposal was challenged by the Attorney General due to concerns about broad releases required from victims and potential misuse of compensation funds. *   **Revised Terms:** The new agreement includes provisions for victim advocates, dedicated funding, protections for victim information, access to FBI Victim Services and Child USA referral services, and budget oversight. *   **Legal Action:** A civil enforcement action was filed against the estate, resulting in liens on the estate’s assets. *   **Goal:** The goal is to allow victims to receive compensation without a lengthy court process, providing justice and closure.

The document details an agreement reached between the Virgin Islands Attorney General’s office and Jeffrey Epstein’s estate lawyers regarding a victim compensation fund. Initially, liens on the estate’s $600 million assets restricted the release of funds due to legal disputes over the fund’s legality and potential misuse. The revised protocol, finalized in June 2020, includes several key reforms: the involvement of a victim advocate and a child sexual abuse expert, dedicated funding for those who haven’t yet come forward, protections for victim information, access to FBI Victim Services, and ongoing reporting requirements. The agreement addresses concerns about broad release demands and ensures the fund’s administration will not be used to defend the estate against legal claims. The Attorney General views this as a significant step toward justice for victims and continuing efforts to hold Epstein accountable.

A revised agreement was reached, incorporating key reforms including: the involvement of a victim advocate, dedicated funding, protections for victim information, and approval of the program’s budget.  This new protocol ensures a more victim-oriented and legally sound process, addressing concerns about potential misuse of funds and offering victims access to crucial support services. The Attorney General continues to pursue legal action against the estate through the CICO lawsuit.

The document details the creation of a Claims Fund Program established by the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein to compensate victims of his abuse. This document is a transcript of a court conference regarding the scheduling of the Jeffrey Epstein case (United States v. Epstein). The judge, Richard M. Berman, convened a meeting with the prosecution and defense attorneys to establish timelines for discovery, motion practice, and ultimately, the trial date. Key points discussed include: *   **Discovery Deadline:** A proposed deadline of October 31 for completing discovery, with a potential extension due to the review of seized electronic devices. A privilege review protocol is being considered. *   **Motion Deadlines:** Proposed deadlines for filing discovery-related motions (September 13), pretrial motions (January 10), with government responses and replies scheduled accordingly. *   **Trial Date:** The government proposed a June 2020 trial date, estimated to last 4-6 weeks, with potential scheduling challenges due to the complexity of the case. The defense requested a preliminary trial date immediately after Labor Day, 2020. *   **Extension Request:** The court granted an extension of Speedy Trial time due to the extensive discovery process and the complexity of the case, excluding time until June 8, 2020. *   **Oral Argument:** Oral argument was scheduled for October 28, 2019, and substantive motions were scheduled for oral argument on March 12, 2020.

The individual declined Siegel’s modeling offer and later had a romantic relationship with a man in Miami who was coached by an unidentified individual. The individual also reported seeing news articles about Scott Borgerson, recognizing him as the man in Miami, and believed encounters with Prince William were also connected to the case.

This document summarizes a court conference regarding the scheduling of the Jeffrey Epstein case (19 Cr. 490(RMB)). The judge, Richard M. Berman, and legal representatives from the United States and the defense (Steptoe & Johnson, LLP) discussed a proposed schedule for discovery, motions, and potentially a trial date. Here’s a breakdown of the key points: *   **Proposed Schedule:** The government proposed a discovery deadline of October 31, acknowledging a delay in reviewing seized electronic devices.  They proposed deadlines for discovery-related motions (September 13), pretrial motions (January 10), and a trial date set for June 2020 (with a 4-6 week trial duration). *   **Defense Concerns:** The defense, represented by Geoffrey S. Berman and Michael C. Miller, expressed concerns about the lengthy timeline, particularly regarding the volume of discovery (over a million pages) and the need for thorough preparation, especially concerning the Nonprosecution Agreement (NPA) and potential double jeopardy issues. They requested a preliminary trial date in September 2020 to allow for assessment of Epstein’s ability to assist in the defense and to review the discovery. *   **Trial Date Discussion:** The court ultimately agreed to a trial date in June 2020, with the government’s four-to-six week estimate. The defense sought a September 2020 date as a placeholder, arguing it was necessary for adequate preparation, given the complexity of the case. *   **Speedy Trial:** The court excluded time from the conference date through June 8, 2020, under 18 U.S.C. § 3161, to avoid impacting speedy trial calculations. An oral argument was scheduled for October 28, 2019, and a further argument was set for March 12, 2020.

Virgin Islands.  The FBI contractor is responsible for extracting and preparing the data for review, while the FBI (specifically the NY CART Coordinator) is overseeing the process. This document is a Search and Seizure Warrant issued on June 26, 2020, related to the investigation of Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The devices were seized to investigate violations of 18 U.S.C. sections 1591, 2422, 2423, and 371 (relating to sex trafficking, transportation of minors, enticement to travel, and conspiracy). Furthermore, the document outlines procedures for inventory, return of property, and filing of the warrant and inventory. Attachment A details the specific devices seized, categorized by their origin and description. The warrant also grants authority to review electronic storage media (ESI) on the seized devices for evidence related to the Subject Offenses.

The primary issue revolves around the disorganized and incomplete delivery of data, particularly concerning the massive volume of files (over a million) recovered from multiple devices (computers, hard drives, CDs, etc.) across New York and the US Virgin Islands.  Key points include: *   **Delayed Data Delivery:** Significant delays are experienced in receiving the data, with estimates fluctuating and needing to be pushed back. *   **Data Organization Issues:** The received data is poorly organized, lacking clear identification of devices and contents, making review extremely difficult. There are multiple versions of files. *   **Relativity System Challenges:** The contractor is attempting to utilize Relativity for data review, but the lack of proper organization hinders its effectiveness. The system is unable to easily interpret the data. *   **Request for a Tracking System:**  The team repeatedly requests a standardized spreadsheet or tracking system to manage the data and facilitate the review process. *   **Ongoing Coordination:** The exchanges involve ongoing discussions about timelines, data formats, and the necessary steps to effectively analyze the evidence. Several individuals coordinate to schedule meetings. *   **Technical Difficulties:** Technical issues, such as network problems and the need to rebuild network infrastructure, contribute to the delays. The core problem is the absence of a clear, organized system for tracking the digital evidence, leading to significant delays and challenges in the investigation.

Attorney's Office, and a contractor (BRG) to analyze data seized during searches related to Jeffrey Epstein. The core issue is a lack of clear organization and tracking of the evidence, leading to repeated delays and confusion. **Key Points:** *   **Data Volume & Complexity:** The investigation involves a massive amount of data across various devices (computers, hard drives, CDs, etc.), making the process incredibly complex. *   **Lack of Tracking:** The primary problem is the absence of a consistent system for identifying and labeling the evidence, making it difficult to determine what’s been reviewed, transferred, and what remains. *   **Processing Issues:** The contractor highlights issues with the data formats received, specifically challenges with Relativity (the e-discovery tool) handling the data and the lack of links between files and devices. *   **Timeline Delays:** Repeated delays are attributed to miscommunication, the need to re-process data, and the sheer volume of evidence. *   **Requests for Clarity:** Throughout the exchanges, the US Attorney's Office and FBI repeatedly request a spreadsheet or other organized listing of the evidence to facilitate the review process. *   **Proposed Solutions:** Various suggestions are made (e.g., creating a spreadsheet, using Bates numbers) to address the tracking problem, but implementation is slow due to the ongoing challenges. Essentially, the document chronicles the frustrating process of trying to manage a large, complex digital evidence case with inadequate organization and communication.

An FBI Supervisory Special Agent (SSA) in New York received an email from EFTA00037267 regarding a potential case involving a former Jeffrey Epstein victim who wishes to disclose information for the first time. The victim, a teenager who visited an island multiple times with Epstein, is being assisted by a detective who seeks guidance. The SSA informed the sender that the case is being handled by the FBI’s Crimes against Children squad (C20) and that the SSA would follow up the next day.

A forwarded email chain discusses sending victim notification letters to clients represented by EPL LLC. The email, dated July 20, 2020, requests confirmation of clients who spoke with the FBI or were identified as victims in a 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement. The email includes a list of claimants, including EFTA00021914, and identifies EPL LLC as the sender and recipient.

An FBI agent in Phoenix contacted an FBI agent in New York regarding a case involving a former Jeffrey Epstein victim who wishes to disclose information for the first time. The victim, a teenager who had visited Epstein on an island, is being assisted by a detective who seeks guidance. The case is being handled by the FBI’s Crimes against Children squad (C20).

On July 20, 2020, an FBI agent in New York (NY) inquired with the FBI’s Phoenix office (PX) regarding a case involving a former Jeffrey Epstein victim who wishes to disclose information for the first time. The victim had been contacted by a detective and requested guidance. The NY FBI agent confirmed the case was being handled by the Crimes against Children squad (C20) and advised the Phoenix agent on how to assist the detective.

*   A former model recounts her experience being recruited for Victoria’s Secret, facilitated by Ghislaine Maxwell. She describes a casting meeting, a “pass,” and subsequent negative repercussions after rejecting unwanted advances. *   The model details a pattern of exploitation within the modeling industry, citing concerns about unrealistic beauty standards and the pressure to conform. *   She shares knowledge of other abuses within the entertainment industry, referencing a BBC documentary exposing photographic industry practices. *   The email concludes with a reflection on the broader scope of trafficking and the ongoing legal issues surrounding Epstein and Maxwell.

An email chain discusses a case involving a former Jeffrey Epstein victim who wishes to disclose information for the first time. A detective in Phoenix contacted someone (identified as EFTA00037506) seeking guidance on how to handle the case, which is currently being handled by the Crimes Against Children squad (C20) of the FBI New York. The email includes correspondence between the detective, the individual seeking guidance, and the NYPD and FBI.

On July 22, 2020, the FBI is finalizing the extraction of data from devices related to the Epstein case. Nearly all remaining device extractions are scheduled to be completed the following day. A drive containing the extracted data will be sent for copying and processing, potentially for upload the following week. A scrubbed and updated spreadsheet is requested to match up the data. The last item is being copied to a drive and will be submitted to Southern, with completion expected the following morning. Hardware data recovery for two servers is outstanding.

Multiple individuals within the USAO (USA Attorney's Office) were contacted regarding a FOIA request for Ghislaine Maxwell’s mugshot. The SDNY (Southern District of New York) did not possess the photograph. One individual indicated that all FOIA inquiries are forwarded to the main point of contact for the case. An intake form request was submitted for discovery production related to the request.

An FOIA request was received for Ghislaine Maxwell’s mugshot. The recipient, a FOIA/PA Staff member in D.C., confirmed they do not possess the photo and are investigating its origin and potential reasons for non-circulation. The request was initially forwarded to an unspecified entity (FBI or DOJ) as the main point of contact, and a separate intake form request for discovery production was submitted.

This document is a series of email exchanges regarding the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell, specifically concerning the location of relevant documents. Key points include: *   Multiple parties (USANYS, USANYS, ODAG, MAO, SDFL, NDGA, OPR) are involved in coordinating efforts to locate documents. *   Requests are made to contact individuals within the Southern District of New York’s (SDFL) Criminal Division, specifically a US Attorney and a Criminal Chief, to obtain copies of criminal files. *   There’s an inquiry about the best point of contact within the SDFL for document retrieval, given prior conversations with OPR and the CVRA litigation. *   Discussions involve identifying document custodians (OPR, M.) and exploring potential contacts within SDFL and NDGA related to document collection. *   A U.S. Attorney’s Office representative offers to discuss recusal issues and directs contact to the SDFL. *   Scheduling of a call for July 22, 2020, to discuss document requests is repeatedly proposed.

This document, originating from the FBI New York Field Office Violent Crimes Task Force, is titled EFTA00032091 and pertains to an investigation involving the USANYS. It includes a zip file named Part_3.zip and was sent on July 23, 2020, to multiple recipients including [REDACTED] and [REDACTED].  Three redactions are present within the document.

An FBI Violent Crimes Task Force Special Agent from the New York Field Office sent an email to [REDACTED] on July 23, 2020, regarding case file EFTA00025401. The email included an attachment named Part_4.zip. The email originated from NY [REDACTED]@[REDACTED] (SANYS, USANYS, USANYS) and identified the sender as a "Contractor."

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] on July 24, 2020, regarding case file EFTA00015849. The email included an attachment named “Part_9.zip” and was sent by the FBI New York Field Office, Violent Crimes Task Force. The sender is identified as a Special Agent with contact information including a desk and cell number.

An email was sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] and [REDACTED] requesting that Will save and track interview notes from the FBI New York Field Office regarding Child Exploitation and Human Trafficking. The notes, titled “interview notes180754.pdf,” are attached to the email. The email reference is EFTA00021758.

An email chain discusses a sign posted in the SHU at MCC during interviews with employees related to Jeffrey Epstein. The email originated from the U.S. Department of Justice, Office of the Inspector General, New York Field Office, and specifically asks if anyone recalled an employee mentioning the sign and if any prior inquiries were made regarding it. A production of records from the BOP was recently received as part of FOIA litigation, including the attached document.

Multiple parties (USDOJ OIG, NY Field Office, USANYS) are investigating a sign reportedly found in the SHU (likely SHU at the Metropolitan Correctional Center). The investigation began with a request to set up an interview with a specific individual.  The OIG wants to interview the individual who possesses the sign, seeking information about its origin, creation, and any associated knowledge.  There is a recollection of an employee mentioning the sign to investigators during interviews at MCC.  Initial searches of 302s and MOIs have not found any record of the sign. A FOIA request produced records related to the sign, and the investigation is ongoing to determine if inquiries were previously made and to identify the individual who created the sign.

On July 28, 2020, a Detective from the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force requested jail calls and emails for inmate Ghislaine Maxwell (BOP# 02879-509). The request was sent to [REDACTED] and their partner, with the Detective CC'd on the email. The Detective requested continued transmission of these communications as they had been previously provided.

Email correspondence regarding the saving and tracking of interview notes from the FBI New York Field Office (Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking) related to case EFTA00020777. The notes were sent to an Epstein share drive and added to a tracker.

An FBI Special Agent (SA) from the New York Field Office (Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking) is seeking volunteers to assist with the Epstein/Maxwell investigation. The SA is requesting assistance with prepping evidence, organizing discovery, reviewing items, and listening to recordings.  A potential volunteer expressed interest on July 29, 2020, offering availability for phone conversations and discussing how to fulfill SOG shifts. The Squad C-20 (VCAC/HT) is specifically involved and highlighted the case's high profile nature.

On July 29, 2020, the FBI New York Field Office (specifically the Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking and Public Corruption squads) requested assistance from other FBI offices, including the NY office, regarding the Epstein/Maxwell investigation. Squad C-20 within the VCAC/HT unit was seeking volunteers due to a significant volume of evidence and a project with a turnaround time of end of August. A supervisor expressed understanding and willingness to assist pending SSA approval. A request for details on time commitment and activity was sent, and a subsequent email outlined the investigation’s scope and requested visibility from relevant agents.

On July 29, 2020, the FBI New York Field Office’s Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking unit (Squad C-20) requested assistance regarding the ongoing Epstein/Maxwell investigation. An initial email circulated requesting availability from individuals to discuss the case and contact the SA and SSA. A subsequent email reiterated the request for assistance and included contact information for the FBI New York Field Office.

The U.S. Department of Justice, via the Southern District of New York, is producing a collection of electronic files related to the case of *United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell*. These files, stamped with control numbers from SDNY_GM_000174967 to SDNY_GM_00328863, include records from Deutsche Bank, JPMorgan Chase, Citibank, UBS, and American Express, pertaining to Ghislaine Maxwell, the Angara Trust, Montepelier Trust, Terramar Project, Inc., Max Foundation, Ghislaine Maxwell IRA, and Ellmax, LLC.  The production is governed by a Protective Order issued on July 31, 2020, and includes instructions for accessing the files (specifically regarding .dat, .dvt, and .vol files and video files), and a commitment from the government to continue producing discoverable materials.

On July 31, 2020, a journalist from the Daily Mail requested information regarding court documents related to the Jeffrey Epstein case. Multiple individuals and organizations, including the DOJ and redacted parties, responded, stating they did not possess the specific document referenced (EFTA00023780) due to its voluminous nature and connection to an unsealed civil suit. The journalist was directed to request a copy of the document directly from the reporter. The inquiry centered on a claim within the documents alleging pressure on the DOJ regarding a plea deal for Epstein.

A journalist from the Daily Mail contacted multiple parties, including the FBI and a legal department ([REDACTED]), regarding a claim in newly unsealed court documents. The journalist’s inquiry concerned allegations that Prince Andrew and Alan Dershowitz pressured the DOJ to offer Jeffrey Epstein a favorable plea deal in 2007, stemming from a civil case involving Ghislaine Maxwell. Initial responses indicated a lack of possession of the specific document referenced and a redirection to request a copy from the reporter.

The U.S. Department of Justice, Southern District of New York, is producing materials related to the case of Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). The materials, stamped with control numbers from SDNY_GM_00328070 to SDNY_GM_00356148, consist of FBI documents, PBPD materials, PBSA materials, scans of FBI evidence, and SDFL materials. The documents are categorized by confidentiality levels: Confidential, Highly Confidential, and Non-Confidential. They include aerial video, FBI documents from Florida and New York, photos, blueprints, and various video recordings from Florida investigations. The production is governed by a July 31, 2020 Protective Order.

An FBI Special Agent (SA) from the New York Field Office (Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking) is seeking volunteers to assist with the Epstein/Maxwell investigation. The SA is requesting assistance with prepping evidence, organizing discovery, reviewing items, and listening to recordings. Several individuals expressed interest, including those from the TD (FBI), NY (FBI), and SOG. A specific time for a conversation was offered for Monday. The investigation involves Squad C-20 (VCAC/HT).

The individual alleges that they were groomed by Epstein and Maxwell, and that their artwork was stolen and subsequently forged and sold through various galleries and auction houses, including Sotheby's and the Smithsonian.  The stolen artwork includes paintings of Bill Clinton and other figures, with a key figure in the alleged scheme being Jeffrey Matthew Settle, an actor who benefited from the disappearance of the art. The individual claims a complex network of individuals, including Tony Podesta, Petrina Ryan Kleid, and J.B. Benn, were involved in the fraudulent activities. The individual spent $100,000 attempting to recover their artwork and believes the art is worth a significant amount of money. The tip was submitted via tips.fbi.gov, and the individual's initial contact information is redacted.
