timeline.summary: On August 3, 2020, an anonymous tipster reported suspected human trafficking involving Jeffrey Epstein and Prince Andrew to the FBI NTOC via tips.fbi.gov. The tip included claims of organized pedophilia, references to specific locations (Bahamas, Ipanema, Brazil, Florianopolis), and the alleged presence of evidence, including keys and tapes. The tipster claimed the activity had been ongoing for 15 years.  A follow-up communication on August 4, 2020, included redacted complainant and witness information, along with details about the subject, Jeffrey Epstein, and the source IP address (Finland) and referrer URL (FBI.gov/tips).

On August 4, 2020, an FBI agent in New York (NY) received a request from an FBI agent in CID to discuss a document provided by the NCA regarding Jeffrey Epstein. The document included financial intelligence from the NCA about Epstein's account and a request to assess if an internal NSPCC investigation into Care Iveagh would impact the NY FBI’s investigation. The NY FBI agent agreed to coordinate with SDNY and the NCA, and indicated they would provide a message to send back.

An FBI agent in New York (NY) forwarded an intelligence document (“NCAWAS-20-081 - Intel for FBI”) to an AMIEME contact and a CID FBI team. The document, provided by the NCA, contains information regarding Jeffrey Epstein and a request for an internal NSPCC investigation into Care Iveagh. The NCA offers to share financial intelligence regarding Epstein, potentially routing it through FinCEN for coordination with the FBI. The sender requests discussion of the document's contents with the SDNY team and asks how to coordinate with the NCA.

FBI agents are investigating the Epstein case, specifically focusing on Deutsche Bank’s role in Epstein’s financial activities. They engaged Morris, Epstein’s attorney, and are seeking to interview Epstein’s attorney and potentially Maxwell, depending on her cooperation. The investigation centers on concerns that Deutsche Bank failed to monitor Epstein’s transactions, particularly regarding the movement of funds related to women and potential witness tampering. The agents are specifically seeking information about who within the FBI squad was handling the case and whether they spoke with Paul Morris, Epstein’s relationship manager at the bank.

*   The investigation relies heavily on FBI 302 reports, transcripts of a grand jury testimony, and documents related to an NPA investigation. *   Jane Doe Number One is mentioned only once in the grand jury testimony, specifically in the context of how she met Epstein at Mar-a-Lago through a connection to Ghislaine Maxwell. *   Maxwell is mentioned in some FBI 302s, but the NPA investigation has found she doesn't appear frequently or at all in reviewed documents. *   There were no federal search warrants, only a local search warrant for a Palm Beach residence for which the SDFL file is unavailable. *   Efforts are being made to obtain the SDFL file and the “pros memo” from OPR to gain a better understanding of the evidence. *   The team is checking the Palm Beach residence search warrant application and confirming if Maxwell was identified as a target/subject in any warrants or materials from the SDFL case.

An email was sent from the FBI to the UNET regarding the upload of files from FBINET to UNET, identified as EFTA00037468. The email included a document named “C-20 SAR 8-07-2020.docx” as an attachment.

On August 10, 2020, an anonymous female caller reported to the FBI that her father, an attorney residing in Tarpon Springs, FL, was a former recruiter for Jeffrey Epstein. The caller, who was 28 years old at the time, claimed she and her siblings were subjected to sex trafficking throughout their childhood, beginning at age four, with her father and other individuals acting as “pimps.” She stated she met Epstein around the time Ghislaine Maxwell was around. The caller described instances of forced sexual activity, a “thumb” controlling her, and a child who expresses fear of her father. She also claimed to have taken a photograph of Prince Andrew and Ghislaine Maxwell in 2001.  The caller is currently seeking full custody of her child and fears he may also be trafficked.

Gloria Allred and her co-counsel, Mariann Wang, contacted an individual to discuss potential victims of Jeffrey Epstein and Maxwell who were willing to speak to the FBI. They requested a call on Wednesday at 2 P.M. EST to discuss questions prior to scheduling client interviews. The communication included contact information for Allred, Maroko & Goldberg and emphasized the confidential nature of the message.

A video conference took place between a Detective from the NYPD I FBI Child Ex loitation Human Trafficking Task Force and [REDACTED] on August 10, 2020. The Detective will contact prosecutors to determine availability for a case involving child exploitation and human trafficking, with an option to include Sigrid.

Discussions center around timing for disclosures, specifically a three-day window before an arrest. There’s concern about the lack of a “pros memo” and a desire to gather information from various sources, including FBI 302 reports and transcripts of a grand jury testimony. The testimony reveals Maxwell met Epstein through a friend, Jane Doe Number One, at Mar-a-Lago. The team is seeking to understand Maxwell’s role in the Florida investigation, examining FBI file 302s and a local search warrant. They are attempting to locate and obtain a copy of the SDFL file, including a pros memo, to gain a more complete picture of the investigation and potential evidence related to Maxwell.

On August 11, 2020, an individual (identified only as “[REDACTED]”) submitted a tip to the FBI National Threat Operations Center reporting a sexual encounter with Jeffrey Epstein in the 2000s. The individual claims to have been 15 at the time and involved in a massage service facilitated by Jeffrey Epstein and his associate, Andy. Andy allegedly facilitated the exploitation of Russian girls for prostitution to wealthy men. The individual seeks confirmation of Epstein’s presence in Virginia Beach, information about Andy’s involvement, and verification of any addresses associated with Epstein. The initial tip included details about a conversation with Andy regarding government involvement and concerns about being pursued. FBI databases yielded no results from Sentinel, Guardian, and DIVS queries. The tip originated from an IP address and referrer linked to the FBI website.

Two emails were exchanged regarding a video conference. Detective from the NYPD I FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force contacted M to schedule a meeting. The Detective had consulted with their team and proposed Monday, August 24th. The Detective also contacted prosecutors to coordinate availability, suggesting Sigrid could be involved if M preferred.

On August 12, 2020, Detective I from the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force offered a video conference on August 24th. This followed a request from another individual for a conference regarding a case involving prosecutors. The Detective stated they would contact the prosecutors to determine availability over the next few weeks and would keep the requester updated. Detective I also noted that Sigrid could be involved if desired.

A series of emails discuss scheduling a video conference between Detective IME (NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force) and another party regarding a case. The initial proposal is for Monday, August 24th. Detective IME will contact prosecutors to determine availability and will involve Sigrid if desired. A previous email indicates the recipient was recovering from oral surgery.

On August 14, 2020, press clippings were compiled regarding several news stories. These included charges related to threats against women involved in the R. Kelly case, Ghislaine Maxwell’s denied prison move, Politico’s article on NRA corruption, misconduct complaints against Mayor de Blasio, NYPD oversight, Trump hinting at firing FBI Director Wray, DHS official eligibility, ProPublica’s coverage of election and cybersecurity issues, a nursing home resident dumping, Tekashi 6ix9ine’s appearance, a Garmin ransomware attack, and Donald Trump’s tax filings.

On August 17, 2020, Jeffrey Epstein reported being approached by Ghislaine Maxwell approximately 28 years prior, when he was 14. Maxwell offered modeling opportunities, international travel, and massages. Epstein recalled working at the Jupiter Gym (now Elite Gym of Palm Beach) and being approached by Maxwell after seeing him on an elliptical machine. He stated he was 14 at the time Maxwell inquired about his age and offered him modeling opportunities, including Victoria Secret and international travel. He declined the offer because he was unable to pursue runway modeling due to a hip defect and believed the offer was primarily centered around modeling.

The tip originated from Maitland, Florida, via tips.fbi.gov. The individual, who was 14-15 years old at the time, worked at a gym daycare in Jupiter, Florida, and reported that Maxwell approached them for modeling opportunities around 1993. The individual had a podcast detailing the encounter. The FBI case ID is 50D-NY-302757I. Redactions obscure personal details of the complainant and witness. The reported IP address resolves to Orlando, Florida.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York is requesting additional discovery materials related to a case, likely involving the Maxwell investigation. Specifically, the requests include: *   Grand jury transcripts from a disc. *   Scans of message pads without post-it notes. *   SW returns for warrants related to mag 6719 and NH premises. *   The full FBI Sentinel file. *   CART paperwork regarding data extraction from seized devices. *   All 302s related to data extraction and image reviews. *   Scans of files provided by Reiter to the FBI. *   Scans of all un-scanned hard copy documents seized during searches, excluding nude/partially nude images (with a log for those). *   Contents of seized discs, excluding nude/partially nude images (with a log for those).

FBI New York is investigating Clare Iveagh, following a request from the NCA. The FBI contacted FBI HQ and CID regarding the investigation. The NCA provided a document and financial intelligence related to Jeffrey Epstein’s accounts, offering to route the information through FinCEN for coordination. SDNY does not see an issue with the internal investigation.

This document is a Palm Beach Police Report sent from [REDACTED] to [REDACTED] on August 19, 2020. It includes an unredacted version of the report, provided by the FBI’s Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. The report is identified as EFTA00029024 and includes two redactions.

The primary parties involved are the FBI (specifically a Special Agent in New York) and the Assistant United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York. Key requests include: *   **Immediate Delivery:** Copies of VHS tapes and microcassettes from Reiter, as well as the FBI file and scans of the FL file and NY/VI evidence. *   **Message Pad Scans:**  Requests for scans of message pads without post-it notes and a copy of the “gj transcript disc.” *   **Evidence Returns:** Requests for paper evidence from NY, VI, and Reiter. *   **CART Paperwork:**  Demand for documentation of data extraction procedures by CART. *   **Longer-Term Requests:**  Requests for the full FBI Sentinel file, all 302s regarding device extractions, scans of Reiter’s files, and scans of all un-scanned hard copy documents (excluding nude images). *   **Image Review:** Requests for access to digital images seized during the investigation, along with detailed logs regarding their location and storage. There’s discussion about scheduling time to review materials in person and a need for additional time to process a large volume of evidence containing nude/semi-nude images. The correspondence highlights a back-and-forth exchange about timelines, delivery methods (disk/thumbdrive), and the need for clarification on various aspects of the investigation’s documentation.

Key points include: *   **Request for Materials:** The USANYS is requesting various FBI documents and scans, including grand jury transcripts, evidence scans, FBI file, returns for warrants, and copies of all seized documents and images. *   **Missing Items:** There are specific requests for missing returns related to warrants (20 mag 6719 and NH premises warrants), CART paperwork regarding data extractions, and 302s related to device extractions and image reviews. *   **Scan Issues:** The FBI is experiencing difficulties providing scans without post-it notes on message pad pages and is working on retrieving copies of non-nude images for production. There's a concern about the volume of evidence requiring extensive processing. *   **Timeline Concerns:** The FBI expresses difficulty meeting the requested timelines, particularly regarding the processing of a large volume of evidence, specifically concerning nude/semi-nude images. *   **Collaboration:** The parties intend to schedule a call to discuss the timeline and outstanding issues.

This document is a series of email exchanges between the Southern District of New York (SDNY) and the FBI regarding the discovery process in a case, likely involving child exploitation and human trafficking. Key points include: *   **Discovery Items Requested:** The SDNY is requesting various items, including scanned documents (message pads, paper evidence, evidence scans), FBI files, returns for warrants, and copies of digital media. *   **Status Updates:** The FBI provides updates on the progress of scanning and organizing the evidence, noting challenges like large volumes of data and the need to remove potentially disturbing images. *   **Missing Materials:** Specific items are identified as missing, such as full FBI Sentinel files, CART paperwork, 302s regarding device extractions, and scans of documents provided by Reiter. *   **Technical Issues:** There are reports of technical difficulties, including large attachment sizes and the need for scans without post-it notes. *   **Timeline Concerns:** Discussions revolve around timelines for receiving the requested materials and scheduling calls to coordinate efforts.

The primary focus is on gathering and organizing evidence, including message pad scans, paper documents, electronic evidence, and disk returns. Key issues include: *   **Missing Materials:** Requests are being made for missing FBI files, CART paperwork, 302s, scans of Reiter’s documents, and scans of hard copy documents (particularly those not yet digitized). *   **Scan Issues:** There are concerns about the quality of provided scans, specifically regarding post-it notes on message pads and the lack of complete scans without them. *   **Timeline Pressure:** There’s a sense of urgency to complete the discovery process, with requests for materials to be provided by specific deadlines (e.g., by Friday). *   **Communication and Coordination:** Frequent email exchanges demonstrate ongoing communication and attempts to coordinate efforts among the involved parties.

The investigation involves a box of media (VHS tapes, cassette tapes, microcassettes, newspaper articles), a thumb drive containing a spreadsheet with highlighted items, and loose disks. Key activities include: *   **Media Conversion:** VHS and cassette tapes are to be converted to digital formats. *   **Redaction:**  The FBI is actively redacting images from the media, focusing on removing potentially disturbing content. *   **Evidence Tracking:** A spreadsheet tracks the inclusion of items based on highlighted criteria. *   **Disk Distribution:**  Disks containing scans and evidence are being prepared and sent to the US Attorney’s office. *   **Ongoing Requests:** The US Attorney is requesting further scanned materials (message pad scans without post-its, SW returns for warrants, full FBI Sentinel files, CART paperwork, scans of Reiter’s documents, and scans of all un-scanned hard-copy documents), and a platform for reviewing the data. Communication is primarily via email between the FBI agents and the US Attorney, with updates and requests for clarification.

On August 20, 2020, a woman contacted the FBI’s National Threat Operations Center reporting she had been contacted by Jeffrey Epstein. She stated she is a victim of Epstein and has been in contact with hundreds of other victims attempting to publish a book. She provided information about Epstein’s connections to prominent business figures like Leslie Wexner and claimed knowledge of criminal activity involving Epstein, President Bill Clinton, President Donald Trump, Maxwell, and films documenting these activities. The woman inquired about who hired Epstein at Bear.

This document details the exchange of discovery materials related to an FBI investigation, likely involving child exploitation and human trafficking, overseen by the US Attorney’s office in the Southern District of New York. Key elements include: *   **Initial Delivery:** A box of media (VHS tapes, cassette tapes, microcassettes, and newspaper articles) provided by Reiter, accompanied by a thumbdrive with a spreadsheet detailing included items. *   **Ongoing Redaction:** The FBI is actively redacting sensitive materials from the discovered media. *   **Requests for Additional Materials:** The US Attorney’s office requests further items, including transcript discs, paper evidence, FBI files, and digital scans without post-it notes. Specifically, they seek copies of grand jury transcripts, returns for warrants, and detailed logs of image scans (particularly concerning potentially sensitive images). *   **Technical Challenges:** The team faces issues with the scanned materials, including discrepancies between versions with and without post-it notes, and a large volume of images requiring review and redaction. *   **Coordination:** Multiple parties – the FBI New York Field Office, NYPD detectives, and the US Attorney’s office – are involved in coordinating the collection, review, and redaction process.

An FBI/NYPD Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force detective initiated contact via email to coordinate a video conference. The initial contact (Aug 20, 2020) inquired about availability on August 24th. A second party (Aug 12, 2020) confirmed availability on the 24th, pending a finalized schedule. A third party (Aug 10, 2020) suggested the 24th as the best date, referencing conversations with their team and pending input from prosecutors regarding Sigrid’s potential involvement in the case.

An individual (Detective MI) is coordinating a video conference with another party regarding a case involving child exploitation and human trafficking. The initial proposed date is Monday, August 24th. A third party (identified as “M”) initially suggested the 24th, but subsequently stated they have a scheduling conflict due to upcoming radiation treatment. Detective MI is contacting prosecutors to determine availability and will update the party on the confirmed date. The communications include discussions regarding Sigrid’s potential involvement.

A series of email exchanges occurred regarding a video conference between multiple parties, including individuals from the NYPD/FBI and the FBI’s Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force. The initial request was for a video conference on Monday, August 24th, at 12:00 noon (Eastern Time) or 1:00 PM (Central Time). One party expressed technical limitations (using an iPhone) and confusion regarding time zones. Another party offered an alternative date of August 24th, but indicated scheduling difficulties. A third party communicated a desire to involve Sigrid and requested she contact the relevant individuals. The emails included well-wishes for recovery and an intention to coordinate availability with prosecutors.

An interview was conducted with a USANYS contractor regarding an interview with a witness concerning Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The witness recalls bringing girls to Epstein who paid him $200 for them, and limited interactions with Maxwell, specifically not discussing bringing girls to the house. The witness provided interview notes which were requested to be saved in a witness folder.

A series of emails discuss scheduling a video conference between an individual (Detective) and another party. The initial proposal is for Monday, August 24th at 1:00 PM Central Time. One party confirms availability, while the other expresses availability for the 24th but indicates they will provide a firm schedule later in the week. A third party offers to coordinate with prosecutors to determine availability, and suggests involving Sigrid if desired. The emails also reference a prior conversation regarding the Detective’s oral surgery and wishes for a speedy recovery.

A series of email exchanges between individuals associated with the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force and an individual identified as “M.” The exchanges primarily concern scheduling a video conference. Initial inquiries propose dates of August 24th, with discussions regarding time zones (Eastern vs. Central) and availability. One party mentions a planned “radiation” event and will provide a schedule closer to the date. Another party expresses well wishes and offers to involve Sigrid in the conference.

This document is a series of emails discussing a request for access to evidence in the US v. Maxwell case (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)). Specifically, Laura Menninger (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C.) is requesting access to FBI-Miami evidence related to Jeffrey Epstein’s activities. The FBI’s New York Office has provided an Excel spreadsheet indexing physical evidence, but notes that it is not comprehensive and includes scans of items within Bates range SDNY_GM_00172218-SDNY_GM_00173007.  A subsequent email confirms the request is approved, and the parties schedule a call to discuss the evidence further.  The emails also reference a previous discovery production from August 21, 2020.

The document is a notification from the U.S. Department of Justice, Southern District of New York, providing additional discovery materials in the case of *United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell*. It details the production of a large collection of documents, emails, photos, and electronic data related to the investigation, including materials from the FBI's Florida office and Jeffrey Epstein’s files.  Specifically, some materials are designated as "highly confidential" due to containing sexually explicit images. The materials are available for pickup at the U.S. Attorney's office and the FBI New York office, with a process for producing electronic copies of certain files. The tip included claims of attempted murder, sterilization, and financial exploitation. The individual’s residential address is Stavanger, Norway. The tip was submitted via the FBI’s tips.fbi.gov website.  The complainant’s contact information includes a cellular phone number and a residential address. The tip included a list of names potentially connected to the trafficking, predominantly from Norway, and the source IP address and referrer URL of the submission. The tip was initially flagged as false regarding a threat to life.

Department of Justice, Southern District of New York, to legal counsel regarding the case of *United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell*. The primary points are: 1.  **Discovery Obligations Met:** The government asserts it has fulfilled its discovery obligations, including the production of electronic materials and initial non-electronic discovery, despite earlier assertions to the contrary. The deadline for electronic discovery was November 9, 2020, and initial discovery was due August 21, 2020. 2.  **Addressing Access at MDC:** The government has taken steps to ensure Maxwell can access discovery materials at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC), including: *   Creating new copies of files in accessible formats upon notification of issues. *   Working with MDC IT to resolve technical difficulties. *   Arranging for MDC staff to adjust the table for note-taking. *   Providing a privacy screen. *   Allowing defense counsel to bring a laptop for review. 3.  **Highly Confidential Material Access:** The government is facilitating the review of approximately 43,500 images seized from Jeffrey Epstein’s residences, initially loading them onto a secure laptop. The FBI is prepared to allow defense counsel and Maxwell to review these images on multiple occasions. 4.  **Conditions of Confinement:** The government has consulted with MDC legal counsel regarding Maxwell’s conditions of confinement. They have addressed concerns regarding: *   Access to discovery time (up to 13 hours daily). *   Body scans (weekly). *   Commissary access (including sports bras and supplemental food). *   Meal provision (with detailed tracking and ensured freshness). *   Mail procedures (following BOP regulations). 5.  **Ongoing Efforts:** The government states it will continue to work with defense counsel and the MDC to address any further issues related to discovery access and confinement conditions.

This document is a correspondence chain between Assistant U.S. Attorney Christian Everdell and defense counsel regarding discovery requests in a case involving Ghislaine Maxwell. Key points include: *   **Delivery of Discovery Materials:** The government has provided Ms. Maxwell with copies of discovery materials, including a 4TB drive containing all previously produced materials and a CD containing documents from November 18, 2020. *   **Metadata and Device Issues:** There are concerns regarding Bates numbers, device identification (SDNY_PROD015/016), and gaps in metadata load files. The government proposes renumbering documents and providing updated DAT files. *   **Missing Documents:** The defense requests the production of missing documents, including AT&T subscriber information and flight logs. *   **Redaction Requests:** The government denies requests for a log of redactions and states they did not apply any redactions to the discovered materials. *   **Subpoena Requests:** The defense requests copies of grand jury subpoenas and the date ranges covered by them. *   **Unsealed Filings:** The government clarifies the status of a search warrant affidavit referenced in a Daily Beast article, stating it was unsealed according to court order and that the District of New Hampshire took no affirmative steps to release it.

Attorney’s office (specifically the Southern District of New York) and defense counsel regarding the discovery process in a case, likely involving Ghislaine Maxwell. Key issues addressed include: *   **Drive Delivery:**  Discussions revolve around the delayed delivery of a 4TB hard drive containing the full discovery production. *   **CD Issues:**  Problems with a CD produced on November 18, 2020, due to a lack of a CD drive on the recipient’s computer. *   **Bates Range Corrections:**  Requests for clarification and correction of Bates number ranges, particularly a lack of correlation between Bates numbers and subject devices. *   **Missing Documents:**  Queries regarding missing documents, specifically subscriber information and flight logs. *   **Metadata Issues:** Problems with metadata load files, including gaps and inconsistencies. *   **Unsealed Documents:** Concerns about the Daily Beast article referencing an unsealed FBI affidavit related to the cell-site simulator, with requests for confirmation of its release. *   **Production Index:** A request for a detailed index of documents produced in the November 9 and November 18 productions. *   **Grand Jury Subpoenas:** Requests for copies of grand jury subpoenas and the date ranges covered by them. timeline.summary: On March 10, 2021, an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York received a call from a woman identifying herself as a former client of Jeffrey Epstein and a former victim. The woman reported contacting her attorney regarding a lack of communication from prosecutors and case agents. The attorney had previously been in contact with an attorney representing the woman for Victim Fund purposes, and had been in touch with an NYPD detective without a response. The attorney documented the call, noting the lack of substantive information and advising a follow-up. The conversation occurred within the context of prior interactions with an attorney who claimed to represent nine Epstein victims, with inconsistent communication and missing complaint information.

This is the FD-794 Payment Request form, version 2.0, revised as of March 11, 2021. It is used by the FBI to request and process payments for authorized expenses, including advance payments and reimbursements. The form collects information such as Social Security Number, case details (case number, date, justification), and employee information. It outlines authorized uses of the data, emphasizes mandatory disclosure, and specifies maintenance within the FBI Central Records System. The form includes sections for approval by various FBI personnel and for finance office settlement of the payment, detailing methods of payment (e.g., cash receipt, OTCnet). Specifically, this form details a request for reimbursement of meals for trial witnesses incurred on 06/12/2021, under case number I50D-NY-3027571.

This is form FD-794, a Payment Request submitted by the FBI. It requests funds for reimbursement of expenses, specifically meals for trial witnesses, incurred by the C-20 unit (E-NY-302757) on 06/23/21. The request is authorized by FBI regulations and E.O. 9397 and 13478. Information collected includes employee details, case information, and justification for the expense. The form includes sections for finance office completion and approval by various FBI supervisory and finance personnel. The overall classification is Unclassified.

This document is a court order denying Ghislaine Maxwell’s request for a Rule 17(c) subpoena to obtain materials related to a case against her. Specifically, the court denied her requests for: *   **A teenage victim’s diary:** The court found that Maxwell’s attempts to use the diary for impeachment or exculpatory evidence were speculative, lacked a clear relevance, and were essentially a “fishing expedition.” The Government already possessed information from the diary, and Maxwell’s attempts to gain access were deemed inappropriate under Rule 17(c). *   **A pair of boots:** The court determined that the Government’s plan to make the boots available to Maxwell for inspection before trial rendered the request moot. *   **Original photographs:** The court similarly found the request for original photographs moot due to the Government’s intention to make scanned copies available, and it was deemed that Maxwell’s attempts to establish relevance for impeachment were insufficient. The court emphasized that Rule 17(c) subpoenas are meant for specific, relevant materials needed for anticipated testimony, not for broad searches or speculative theories.

This document is a redacted investigation into the ownership and movement of several aircraft, primarily focusing on those linked to Jeffrey Epstein. It details a series of transfers involving aircraft registered under various names (Air Ghislaine, Shmitka Air, Freedom Air International, Hyperion Air, and others) over a period from 2008 to 2021. Key individuals involved include Larry VISOSKI, Darren K. Indyke, and Jeffrey EPSTEIN. The investigation traced the aircraft’s ownership through multiple companies and jurisdictions, including Delaware, the U.S. Virgin Islands, Canada, and Connecticut.  The document outlines a pattern of name changes and tail number alterations, alongside the involvement of title companies like Insured Aircraft Title Service and Aero Records and Title Co.  It culminates with the FAA providing further documentation and contacts for continued investigation. The email exchange indicates an ongoing investigation by the FBI and the FAA, requesting information about the aircraft’s history and ownership to support a case involving Jeffrey Epstein.

This document details the redaction and investigation of FAA records pertaining to aircraft registrations, primarily focusing on those linked to Jeffrey Epstein. Initially, a paralegal specialist produced FAA records related to several aircraft, including N415LM, N212JE, and N550GP, after encountering password-locked files. These files involved registrations dating back to the 1990s and 2000s, with multiple owners and operators, including Air Ghislaine Inc., Freedom Air International Inc., and Hyperion Air LLC.  Numerous individuals, such as Darren K. Indyke and Lawrence VISOSKI, were repeatedly involved in the ownership and management of these aircraft. DEA S/A and the FBI in Atlanta expressed interest in the investigation, requesting assistance and providing search terms.  The investigation uncovered complex transfer histories, changes in tail numbers, and connections between the aircraft and individuals of interest, including Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell. The investigation culminated in offers to provide blue ribbon certified copies of the aircraft registration records.

This document details a redaction analysis concerning aircraft registration records, primarily focusing on aircraft previously owned by Jeffrey Epstein and associated entities. The core investigation centers around the movement and ownership history of several aircraft, including an S-76C helicopter (N750A/N722JE/N722JE), a Gulfstream GV-SP (N415LM), a Beech 400A (N491GM), a Sikorsky S-76C (N162AD), a 1969 Boeing 727 (N505LS/N908JE), and a 1974 Gulfstream G-1159B (N979GA).  Multiple individuals, including Larry VISOSKI, Darren K. INDYKE, and Jeffrey EPSTEIN, are repeatedly associated with these aircraft transfers and registrations through various companies like Air Ghislaine, Shmitka Air, Freedom Air International, ASI Wings, Hyperion Air, and others. Insured Aircraft Title Service in Oklahoma played a significant role in facilitating many of these transactions.  The investigation highlights a complex web of ownership changes and connections to Jeffrey Epstein, with the FBI and DEA S/A actively involved in tracking these aircraft. The document includes multiple requests for information and subsequent communications between the FAA and law enforcement agencies, culminating in a request for copies of aircraft registration records. Finally, the document outlines the attempted tracking of other potentially connected entities such as Ghislaine Maxwell, Thomas World Air LLC, Hyperion Air LLC, Freedom Air Petroleum LLC, NES LLC, Maple, Inc., and Nautilus Inc.

*   The core topic of the exchange was the preparation and distribution of “spreadsheets” originating from Denver exports, specifically regarding materials that lacked thumbnails. *   Requests were made to update cover letters, including modifying Bates ranges and removing the word "discovery" from a PDF title. *   A production of documents was prepared and shared via a shared DOJ cloud storage location. *   The sender offered to convert the materials to PDF and send them to MDC (likely a client) for review. *   The sender provided a link to the shared production files. *   There were requests for immediate delivery of the materials.

An Assistant United States Attorney from the Southern District of New York sent an email requesting the recipient (likely FBI/TFO) to send a subpoena to an individual named “him.” The email was dated November 15, 2021, and referenced case file EFTA00037011.

Ghislaine Maxwell* on November 29, 2021, at 9:00 a.m. in Courtroom 906, 40 Foley Square. Multiple individuals were coordinating the distribution of scanned documents, including a black address book and yellow legal pad notes, related to a case (referenced as SDNY_GM_02753612). The materials were associated with the NYPD/FBI Child Exploitation Human Trafficking Task Force.

The FBI New York Field Office’s Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking Special Agent received an email from the FAA Information Management Division regarding FOIA requests for historical flight data of Jeffrey Epstein’s aircraft (N908JE, N909JE, N212JE, and N120JE). The FAA had previously withheld this data due to an FBI criminal investigation. An FAA FOIA release inadvertently included these flight records, prompting the FAA to implement measures to redact similar requests moving forward, specifically regarding the Traffic Flow Management System (TFMS) repository.

The FBI New York field office received notification from the FAA regarding inadvertently released historical flight data for Jeffrey Epstein’s aircraft (N9081E, N9091E, N212JE, and N120JE). The FAA had previously withheld this data due to an FBI criminal investigation (50D). An FOIA request from Angela Wang was denied twice due to exemption 7A. Subsequent release of data from the TFMS repository included the aforementioned aircraft records, prompting the FAA to implement measures to prevent future release of this specific data.

A request was made for travel approval to California for trial preparation related to the upcoming Maxwell trial. A communication chain regarding a voice message received from an individual claiming to have information about Ghislaine Maxwell and being a friend of George Soros. This document is an FBI New York Field Office Special Agent memo regarding a Federal Trial Subpoena (EFTA00010143) related to child exploitation and human trafficking. The memo includes email correspondence and was generated on December 24, 2021.

An email chain discusses information related to Jeffrey Epstein, originating from an individual in Detroit and forwarded to the FBI - New York Office, Child Exploitation and Human Trafficking Task Force. On December 6, 2022, the U.S. Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General’s New York Field Office received a case closing communication from the FBI regarding their investigation into the death of Federal Bureau of Prison inmate Jeffrey Epstein. The FBI determined there was no criminality related to Epstein’s death and closed the case (90A-NY-3151227) on December 5, 2022. An electronic communication detailing the case closing was attached.

*   Bill Barr initially expressed concern about public perception regarding Epstein’s death and subsequently launched an investigation, followed by a swift and forceful public statement. *   Despite promises of accountability, no comprehensive report has emerged from the FBI or Justice Department Office of Inspector General. *   Two low-level guards were charged with falsifying records but had the charges dropped by an Obama-appointed judge. *   The segment highlights the lack of cooperation from individuals involved, including the DOJ case officer, Mr. Lyeson Daniel, who refused to confirm his involvement. *   Carlson questions the circumstances surrounding Epstein’s death, including the locking of his cell, the movement of his body, and the identity of those involved in the procedures. *   The segment concludes with a call for the new Republican Congress to investigate the lack of accountability and demand the truth.

On February 23, 2023, Mark E. Stein submitted a tip to the FBI NTOC via tips.fbi.gov alleging that Jeffrey Epstein was murdered in his jail cell, specifically stating a possible involvement of President Trump. The tip included the assertion that Epstein was about to “name names.” Stein’s contact information, including IP address, DOB, and submitted text, were recorded. The incident was categorized as “Other” with no emergency or threat to life designation.  The NTOC provided contact information for further assistance and mentioned the possibility of drafting a Guardian containing this information. EFTA00038986 and EFTA00038987 were associated with this intake.

*   The sender expresses regret for not testifying and distancing themselves from the case. *   Multiple individuals (detectives, FBI, and others) engaged in email exchanges regarding scheduling a call to discuss the case and potential interview opportunities. *   Dates and times were proposed for a meeting, including Thursday at 6am, Wednesday morning, and the following morning. *   A link was offered to be sent by the team. *   There are redactions present throughout the document.

On April 10, 2023, the Department of Justice’s Office of the Inspector General distributed a draft report titled “Investigation and Review of the Federal Bureau of Prisons’ Custody, Care, and Supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York, New York” to the FBI for review. The purpose was to allow the FBI to conduct a factual accuracy and sensitivity review of the report before its public release. The OIG requested the FBI to flag any inappropriate information for release, maintain a log of access, and emphasize the prohibition on further dissemination. The deadline for the FBI’s review and response was April 17, 2023.

On April 10, 2023, the Office of the Inspector General (OIG) of the Department of Justice released a draft report investigating the custody, care, and supervision of Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in New York. The draft report is intended for review by the FBI for factual accuracy and sensitivity. The FBI is requested to provide feedback by April 17, 2023, with restrictions on dissemination and discussion of the draft report outside of designated FBI personnel.

A lawyer (Daniel Ruzumna) from Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler LLP is communicating with an FBI Special Agent (Young) regarding the review of approximately 1,100 videos recovered from Jeffrey Epstein’s emails. The Estate of Jeffrey Epstein is responding to document requests related to settlements and subpoenas. During the review, a video surfaced potentially containing child pornography, prompting a halt and communication with co-counsel (Dan Weiner and Hilary McDonnell) at Hughes Hubbard & Reed. The documents were processed by a vendor and not downloaded to firm servers. The communication seeks guidance from the FBI.

An FBI Special Agent from the New York Field Office contacted Daniel Ruzumna regarding a potential discovery of Child Sexual Abuse Material (CSAM) related to the Estate of Jeffrey Epstein. Ruzumna, representing one of the co-executors of the estate alongside Hughes Hubbard & Reed, was reviewing approximately 1,100 videos pulled from Epstein’s emails and files. During a review, a video surfaced potentially containing child pornography, linked to a convicted child pornography offender and topless women.  Due to this, the review was halted, and Ruzumna requested guidance from the FBI. The video was processed by a document collection vendor without review, and no downloads occurred to law firm servers.

*   The review is prompted by a potential discovery of child pornography within the videos. *   A video containing topless women was identified by Hughes Hubbard & Reed co-counsel, linked to an individual convicted of child pornography offenses. *   The review was halted, and contact was made with the FBI New York Field Office. *   The estate is responding to document requests related to settlements and subpoenas. *   The videos were processed by a document collection vendor without full review.

Daniel Ruzumna, representing the estate of Jeffrey Epstein, contacted Special Agent Ruzumna at the FBI New York Field Office regarding a potential discovery of child pornography within approximately 1,100 videos recovered from Epstein’s emails.  The estate was responding to document production requests related to settlements and subpoenas. During a review, a video surfaced containing potentially illegal content, prompting the immediate halt of the review.  The estate contacted the FBI and acknowledged the involvement of co-counsel from Hughes Hubbard & Reed, seeking guidance and confirming protocols were in place to protect reviewers. The video’s origin involved a convicted child pornography offender and two topless women. The documents involved the processing of the videos by a document collection vendor without review.

Hilary McDonnell (Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP) scheduled a meeting with Daniel Ruzumna (Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler LLP) regarding the Epstein Estate and a potential discovery of child pornography within 1,100 videos. Ruzumna contacted the FBI New York Field Office after a video surfaced during a review, potentially containing CSAM and referencing a prior conviction for a similar offense. The Estate’s co-executors were reviewing the videos as part of document production obligations related to settlements and litigation. A protocol was established with involved parties for handling potentially illegal material. The review was halted, and Ruzumna requested guidance from the FBI. The communication involved multiple individuals including FBI Special Agents, attorneys from Hughes Hubbard & Reed, and other legal counsel.

*   **Discovery of Potentially Child Pornographic Video:** During a review of approximately 1,100 videos, a video containing a convicted child pornography offender and topless women was identified. *   **Protocol Established:** A protocol was established with involved parties to protect reviewers during the document review process. *   **Suspension of Review & Request for Guidance:** The review was halted, and Ruzumna requests guidance from the FBI regarding the potentially sensitive material. *   **Data Handling Concerns:** Ruzumna expresses concerns about the processing of the videos by a third-party vendor and the lack of downloads to firm servers. *   **Legal Representation:** Both Ruzumna and McDonnell represent co-executors of the estate, with McDonnell’s firm providing legal support in related litigation.

The email contains privileged/confidential information and a warning about potential recipients not being authorized to receive the message. The document is identified as EFTA00038994.

Hilary McDonnell, an associate at Hughes Hubbard & Reed LLP, is coordinating with the FBI regarding the review of videos from the Epstein Estate for potential Child Sexual Abuse Material (CSAM). The review involves approximately 1,100 videos pulled from Epstein’s emails and files. McDonnell is scheduling meetings with FBI Special Agent Daniel Ruzumna and his team at Patterson Belknap Webb & Tyler LLP to discuss the findings. Federal Bureau of Investigation*. The motion was related to a FOIA case where the FBI withheld Epstein’s investigative file entirely under exemption 7(A), citing the Maxwell prosecution.  While other exemptions were asserted, the judge only ruled on 7(A). The case was subsequently terminated with motions for summary judgment dismissed and the case closed. Parties involved included Kirti Vaidya Reddy, Daniel Richard Novack, and Allison from the US Department of Justice.

The document details the FBI investigations into Jeffrey Epstein, initiated by the FBI Miami and FBI New York. Initial investigations (2005-2018) involved interviews with approximately 35 victims, searches of residences in Florida and New York, and analysis of records. Epstein was charged with sex trafficking of minors and conspiracy to commit sex trafficking in 2019. Following his arrest and suicide in 2019, investigations expanded to include associates like Ghislaine Maxwell. Maxwell was ultimately indicted and convicted in 2021, receiving a 20-year sentence.

On August 21, 2024, an individual reported to the FBI NTOC that they were a victim of sex trafficking by Jeffrey Epstein between 1989 and 1996 in Manhattan, NY. The individual alleges being trafficked by MI, having their marriage ruined, and being blackmailed by Epstein’s crew. They also claim to have been assaulted and threatened with a stun gun in 1990.  A second individual, Jeffrey Epstein, is identified as a subject of the report.  A third victim, whose details are redacted, is also named. The NTOC forwarded the information for situational awareness and potential action.

A lawsuit has been filed in the District of D.C. by Merson Law claimants regarding administrative claims. This lawsuit follows a previously dismissed lawsuit in the SDNY district, which was voluntarily dismissed after the court denied motions to proceed anonymously. The Assistant General Counsel of the FBI’s Litigation Branch is monitoring the situation and will provide updates.

On October 17, 2024, the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) Office of the Inspector General (OIG), via Special Agent S, transferred custody of evidence related to DOJ OIG Case Number 2019-010614 to the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI). The evidence included: 16 Redwell Folders containing FBI CARTS Clone of Metropolitan Correctional Center New York (MCC New York) DVR system hard drives, 18 hard drives from FBI Lab # HQQ190816001 containing Clone of MCC New York DVR 1 System, a Magneto Optical Storage with FBI CART Archive, a Diamond Audio MP3 Player with headphones, and several Redwell Folders containing supporting documents and analysis.  Supporting documentation, including custody forms and logs, were also provided.

On October 22, 2024, an individual (identified as [REDACTED]) contacted the FBI NTOC reporting allegations of human trafficking involving Jeffrey Epstein. The individual claims to have been trafficked since age five, detailing experiences including throat cutting, relocation to Fresno, CA, rape in Paris, and involvement with politicians and notable men on Epstein Island. The individual, currently seeking asylum in Germany, possesses photos to substantiate her claims and has previously reported similar cases to multiple FBI offices. Jeffrey Epstein is listed as a subject of the report, with DOB information redacted. The NTOC offers assistance via telephone or email (reference transaction number mpvj623r) and indicates the possibility of drafting a Guardian document upon request from the NY Field Office.

An FBI Victim Specialist in the New York Division is forwarding a message from a victim in a separate “HT case” to address a concern related to an Epstein victim. The message is attached.

Two FBI agents, a Special Agent from the FBI New York Field Office (Child Exploitation/Human Trafficking Desk) and a Victim Specialist from the FBI New York Division, are involved in a separate Human Trafficking (HT) case. Gloria Allred represented the Epstein victim and controlled communication with individuals, requiring all interactions to go through her. The Special Agent provided Gloria Allred with victim resource information and was unable to directly contact the Epstein victim due to her refusal to share contact details.

It also references a black book containing addresses of minors linked to “massage” services, with sections redacted from a trial exhibit. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida’s 2006-2008 federal investigation of Jeffrey Epstein and its interactions with victims.  It was generated on December 24, 2025. The investigation, initiated in 2005 following a complaint about Epstein, led to a state indictment in 2006. The FBI subsequently opened a federal investigation, leading to a draft indictment and a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) negotiated and signed in 2007.  The NPA involved Epstein pleading guilty to state charges and agreeing to specific conditions, including registering as a sexual offender. The Department of Justice Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) investigated allegations that the USAO improperly resolved the case by negotiating the NPA and failing to consult with victims. OPR focused on the actions of the U.S. Attorney, three supervisors, and the Assistant U.S. Attorney involved. The investigation involved a lengthy period of negotiation, with Epstein’s attorneys attempting to modify the NPA terms.  The government ultimately entered into the NPA, securing Epstein’s guilty plea and incarceration.  Following the NPA’s signing, a victim filed a lawsuit alleging a violation of the Crime Victims’ Rights Act (CVRA) due to the government’s failure to consult with victims. OPR found that while the USAO’s handling of the case resulted in poor judgment and a lack of transparency regarding its communications with victims, none of the involved individuals committed professional misconduct.  Specifically, OPR determined that the NPA was not a violation of any legal standards, and while there were shortcomings in the government’s interactions with victims that contributed to public criticism, the government did not act with ill intent or a deliberate effort to silence or mislead victims. The investigation concluded with Epstein’s death in 2018 and the dismissal of the federal charges, as well as a court’s dismissal of the CVRA case due to the case’s “mook” status. OPR noted that the USAO’s lack of transparency contributed to negative public perception and underscored the importance of government communication with victims of crime.
